AlzheiMarkers: Analyzing Alzheimer's Biomarkers with Machine Learning

Source: vignettes/AlzheiMarkers.Rmd
AlzheiMarkers.Rmd

Abstract

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder that affects millions of people worldwide. Early diagnosis and differentiation from healthy aging remain critical challenges in the field. Metabolomic biomarkers present a promising avenue for addressing these challenges by providing insights into the metabolic changes associated with AD (Jia et al. 2021). This article introduces the AlzheiMarkers R package, which facilitates the analysis and evaluation of metabolomic biomarkers for distinguishing Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) patients from Healthy Controls (HC). The package includes functions for data preparation, model training, evaluation, and visualization of biomarker importance and model performance through ROC curves.

Keywords

Alzheimer’s Disease, Metabolomics, Biomarkers, Machine Learning, R Package, Random Forest, XGBoost

1. Introduction

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, accounting for an estimated 60-80% of cases. Despite extensive research, AD diagnosis still relies largely on clinical evaluation and neuroimaging, often identifying the disease at a relatively advanced stage. Metabolomics, the study of metabolites in biological samples, has emerged as a novel tool for biomarker discovery in AD. Numerous studies suggest that metabolic dysregulation plays a critical role in AD pathogenesis.

The AlzheiMarkers R package was developed to support the analysis of metabolomic data for the discovery of potential biomarkers of Alzheimer’s disease. This package allows users to efficiently load and preprocess datasets, split data into training and testing sets, train machine learning models, and visualize model performance. It integrates widely used machine learning algorithms to distinguish AD patients from Healthy Controls (HC).

2. Materials and Methods

2.1 Package Overview

The AlzheiMarkers package contains multiple functions that streamline the workflow from data preparation to model evaluation and visualization. The primary goals of the package are to facilitate metabolomic biomarker analysis and enable the exploration of classification models for differentiating between AD and HC samples.

2.2 Data Preparation

The first step involves data preparation, where raw data are imported and separated into two groups: AD patients and HC. The prepare_data() function reads in a CSV file and returns the full dataset, alongside separated subsets for AD and HC.

prepare_data <- function(file_path) {
  data <- data.table::fread(file_path)
  data <- as.data.frame(data)
  HC <- dplyr::filter(data, Cohort == "HC")
  AD <- dplyr::filter(data, Cohort == "AD")
  
  list(
    data = data,
    HC = HC,
    AD = AD
  )
}

2.3 Data Splitting

After the data is prepared, it is split into training and test sets using the split_data() function. This function provides flexibility in defining the ratio of the dataset that will be used for training.

2.4 Model Training

The AlzheiMarkers package supports the training of multiple machine learning models, including Lasso regression, Random Forest, Naive Bayes, Partial Least Squares (PLS), and XGBoost. Each model is trained using cross-validation with user-specified parameters. The train_models() function integrates the caret package, a powerful tool for building and tuning machine learning models (Kuhn 2008).

train_models <- function(train_data, n_cv = 10, n_repeat = 10) {
  set.seed(123)
  control <- caret::trainControl(
    method = "repeatedcv",
    number = n_cv,
    repeats = n_repeat,
    classProbs = TRUE,
    summaryFunction = caret::twoClassSummary
  )
  
  predictors <- train_data %>% dplyr::select(-Cohort)
  response <- train_data$Cohort
  
  models <- list(
    lasso = caret::train(x = predictors, y = response,
                         method = "glmnet", metric = "ROC", 
                         trControl = control),
    rf = caret::train(x = predictors, y = response, 
                      method = "rf", metric = "ROC", 
                      trControl = control),
    nb = caret::train(x = predictors, y = response, 
                      method = "naive_bayes", metric = "ROC", 
                      trControl = control),
    pls = caret::train(x = predictors, y = response, 
                       method = "pls", metric = "ROC", 
                       trControl = control),
    xgb = caret::train(x = predictors, y = response, 
                       method = "xgbTree", metric = "ROC", 
                       trControl = control)
  )
  
  models
}

2.5 Model Evaluation and Visualization

Once the models are trained, their performance can be evaluated using the evaluate_models() function, which provides various evaluation metrics such as Area Under the ROC Curve (AUC). In addition, the package includes the plot_roc_curves() function to visualize the ROC curves for each model and plot_variable_importance() to plot the most important variables driving the predictions.

plot_roc_curves <- function(eval_results) {
  ggplot2::ggplot(eval_results$roc, ggplot2::aes(x = 1 - Specificity, 
                                                 y = Sensitivity, 
                                                 color = Model)) +
    ggplot2::geom_line() +
    ggplot2::geom_abline(intercept = 0, slope = 1, linetype = "dashed") +
    ggplot2::theme_minimal() +
    ggplot2::labs(title = "ROC Curves for Different Models")
}

2.6 Package Vignette

A vignette is provided with the package to guide users through a typical analysis workflow, including data preparation, model training, and visualization.

3. Results

Using the AlzheiMarkers package, users can efficiently train and evaluate multiple machine learning models to identify potential biomarkers. By visualizing ROC curves, users can determine which models provide the highest diagnostic accuracy for distinguishing AD from HC samples. The variable importance plots offer insights into the most influential biomarkers.

4. Discussion

The AlzheMarkers package provides a user-friendly interface for conducting biomarker discovery and machine learning-based classification in the context of Alzheimer’s Disease. While the package supports several common machine learning methods, it can be further expanded to include additional techniques and functionalities such as feature selection, ensemble modeling, and deep learning approaches.

5. Conclusion

The AlzheiMarkers R package is a tool for analyzing metabolomic biomarkers and differentiating AD patients from healthy controls using machine learning techniques. By providing functions for data preparation, model training, evaluation, and visualization, it simplifies the biomarker discovery process in Alzheimer’s research.

6. References

Jia, Longfei, Jianwei Yang, Min Zhu, Yana Pang, Qi Wang, Qin Wei, Ying Li, et al. 2021. “A Metabolite Panel That Differentiates Alzheimer’s Disease from Other Dementia Types.” Alzheimer’s & Dementia 18 (7): 1345–56. https://doi.org/10.1002/alz.12484.
Kuhn, Max. 2008. “Building Predictive Models inRUsing thecaretPackage.” Journal of Statistical Software 28 (5). https://doi.org/10.18637/jss.v028.i05.
